Internet-Draft J. Quilbeuf Internet-Draft J. Quilbeuf
Intended status: Standards Track B. Claise Intended status: Standards Track B. Claise
Expires: 9 May 2024 Huawei Expires: 2 September 2024 Huawei
6 November 2023 1 March 2024
YANG Full Include YANG Full Embed
draft-jouqui-netmod-yang-full-include-00 draft-jouqui-netmod-yang-full-include-01
Abstract Abstract
YANG lacks re-usability of models defined outside of the grouping and YANG lacks re-usability of models defined outside of the grouping and
augmentation mechanisms. For instance, it is almost impossible to augmentation mechanisms. For instance, it is almost impossible to
reuse a model defined for a device in the context of the network, i.e reuse a model defined for a device in the context of the network, i.e
by encapsulating it in a list indexed by device IDs. [RFC8528] by encapsulating it in a list indexed by device IDs. [RFC8528]
defines the YANG mount mechanism, partially solving the problem by defines the YANG mount mechanism, partially solving the problem by
allowing to include schemas at deploy or runtime. This document aims allowing to mount an arbitrary set of schemas at an arbitrary point.
to provide the same mechanism at design time. However, YANG mount is only focusing on deploy or runtime. This
document aims to provide the same mechanism at design time.

In this document, we propose a new extension, named full include. In this document, we propose a new extension, named full embed. This
This extension enables reusing imported modules by rooting them at an extension enables reusing imported modules by rooting them at an
arbitrary point of the data model. The concept of mount point from arbitrary point of the data model. The concept of mount point from
[RFC8528] is replaced by a list of "full:include" statement, each [RFC8528] is replaced by an anydata statement containing list of
statement corresponding to the inclusion of one imported module at "full:embed" statement, each statement corresponding to the inclusion
that location. In that sense, the design time solution is a pure of one imported module at that location. In that sense, the design
YANG solution that does not rely on external configuration to specify time solution is a pure YANG solution that does not rely on external
the list of mounted modules, hence the term full include rather than configuration to specify the list of mounted modules, hence the term
mount. full embed rather than mount. Also, we use 'embed' not to conflict
with the native 'include' statement in YANG [RFC7950].

3. Full Include 3. Full Embed
The full include mechanism defined in this document completes The full embed mechanism defined in this document completes
[RFC8528], by providing a mechanism to "mount" modules at design [RFC8528], by providing a mechanism to "mount" modules at design
time. Supporting mounting modules at this step of the data model time. Supporting mounting modules at this step of the data model
life cycle is left out of scope in [RFC8528]. life cycle is left out of scope in [RFC8528].
The approach for supporting the full include mechanism is to keep the The approach for supporting the full embed mechanism is to keep the
semantics of [RFC8528] for the resulting data model. In [RFC8528], semantics of [RFC8528] for the resulting data model. In [RFC8528],
the list of modules to mount in each mount point is left to the the list of modules to mount in each mount point is left to the
NETCONF server. In this document, we propose the full include NETCONF server. In this document, we propose the full embed
mechanism to define this mapping directly in the YANG module that mechanism to define this mapping directly in the YANG module that
includes the mounted modules. embeds the mounted modules.
To ensure interoperability with clients that do not support the full
embed extension, the full embed statement can only appear within an
anydata node. Clients that do not support the extension will see the
contents of the embedded model as arbitrary data. Clients that
support the extension will be able to interpret the contents of the
anydata node according to the semantics of the embedded YANG modules.
In the sequel, we use "full" as the prefix for the module 'ietf-yang- In the sequel, we use "full" as the prefix for the module 'ietf-yang-
full-include' (see Section 4). Thus "full:include" refers to the full-embed' (see Section 4). Thus "full:embed" refers to the
extension 'include' defined in that module. extension 'embed' defined in that module.
3.1. Definition 3.1. Definition
The "full:include" statement can appear as a sub-statement of the The "full:embed" statement can appear as a sub-statement of anydata.
following statements:
* container
* list
The "full:include" statement takes as an argument a prefix, that must The "full:embed" statement takes as an argument a prefix, that must
be the prefix associated to an imported module. Modules can contain be the prefix associated to an imported module. Modules can contain
multiple uses of the "full:include" statement. The "container" and multiple uses of the "full:embed" statement. An "anydata" statement
"list" statements MAY contain multiple uses of the "full:include" MAY contain multiple uses of the "full:embed" statement. These
statement on the same level. These multiple uses define the full multiple uses define the full list of modules to be embedded, rooted
list of modules to be included, rooted in node where the in the anydata node where the "full:embed" statement is used.
"full:include" statement is used.
The "full:include" statement can be interpreted using YANG Schema The "full:embed" statement can be interpreted using YANG Schema Mount
Mount [RFC8528], by following these steps: [RFC8528], by following these steps:
1. For each set of "full:include" statement located in the same 1. For each anydata node containing a set of "full:embed" statement,
node, replace them by a single "mount-point" with a unique label. replace them by a container containing single "mount-point" with
a unique label.
2. Declare each of these "mount-points" as "shared-schema" in the 2. Declare each of these "mount-points" as "shared-schema" in the
data model defined in [RFC8528]. data model defined in [RFC8528].
3. In the instance corresponding to each "mount-point", define the 3. In the instance corresponding to each "mount-point", define the
ietf-yang-library [RFC8525] to include a module-set (at '/yang- ietf-yang-library [RFC8525] to include a module-set (at '/yang-
library/module-set/) with the following. The list 'module' library/module-set/) with the following. The list 'module'
contains an entry for every module referred to in the set of contains an entry for every module referred to in the set of
"full:include" statements corresponding to the "mount-point". "full:embed" statements corresponding to the "mount-point".
Additionally, the list 'module' contains an entry for "ietf-yang- Additionally, the list 'module' contains an entry for "ietf-yang-
library" as it is needed by YANG Schema mount. As usual, the library" as it is needed by YANG Schema mount. As usual, the
list 'imported-modules' contains the list of dependencies needed list 'imported-modules' contains the list of dependencies needed
by the modules in the 'module' list. by the modules in the 'module' list.
An example of module using "full:include" and its translation into a An example of module using "full:embed" and its translation into a
similar YANG Schema mount version is presented in Appendix B. similar YANG Schema mount version is presented in Appendix B.
3.2. Limitations 3.2. Limitations
* A module MUST NOT use the "full:include" statement with its own A module MUST NOT use the "full:embed" statement with its own prefix
prefix as argument. This rule prevents any infinite recursion in as argument. This rule prevents any infinite recursion in the
the mounted schemas. mounted schemas.
* Modules used as arguments for the "full:include" statement MUST be As for YANG Schema Mount, the set of embedded modules is an
valid and compile successfully, independently of the module it is independent YANG context, where every reference (for instance leaf-
used in. ref, augment, when) is contained in that context. It is not possible
for an embedded module to refer to the embedding module, which would
be rejected by the compiler anyway because it would create a
dependency loop. If a server supports a module both at top-level and
embedded in another module, the corresponding data instances are
disjoint.
4. ietf-full-include YANG module Activation of the features for the embedded module follows the same
rules as for normal module. Therefore its not possible to activate
some features for some embedded modules only. The feature is either
supported by the server and then activated for every module (embedded
or not) or not supported and then deactivated for all modules
(embedded or not).
We present in this section the YANG module defining the "full- 3.3. Allowed sub-statements
include" extension. The module in itself defines solely the
'include' extension. A module importing this extension SHOULD the
prefix 'full', so that the statement reads "full:include" when used
in the code.
<CODE BEGINS> file "ietf-full-include@2023-11-03.yang" The following sub-statements are allowed in the "full:embed"
module ietf-yang-full-include { statement:
* when
* if-feature
Both statements have the same meaning as in [RFC7950]. The when
statement MUST NOT refer to nodes which are in the embedded module
designated by the "full:embed" statement.
4. ietf-full-embed YANG module
We present in this section the YANG module defining the "full-embed"
extension. The module in itself defines solely the 'embed'
extension. A module importing this extension SHOULD use the prefix
'full', so that the statement reads "full:embed" when used in the
code.
<CODE BEGINS> file "ietf-full-embed@2023-11-03.yang"
module ietf-yang-full-embed {
yang-version 1.1; yang-version 1.1;
namespace "urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-yang-full-include"; namespace "urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-yang-full-embed";
prefix full; prefix full;
organization organization
"IETF NETMOD (NETCONF Data Modeling Language) Working Group"; "IETF NETMOD (NETCONF Data Modeling Language) Working Group";
contact contact
"WG Web: <https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/netmod/> "WG Web: <https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/netmod/>
WG List: <mailto:netmod@ietf.org> WG List: <mailto:netmod@ietf.org>
Editor: "; Editor: ";
description description

see the RFC itself for full legal notices."; see the RFC itself for full legal notices.";
revision 2023-11-05 { revision 2023-11-05 {
description description
"Initial revision."; "Initial revision.";
reference reference
"RFC XXXX: YANG Full Include"; "RFC XXXX: YANG Full Include";
} }
extension include { extension embed {
argument prefix; argument prefix;
description description
"The argument 'prefix' MUST be the prefix of a module imported "The argument 'prefix' MUST be the prefix of a module imported
by the calling module. by the calling module.
The 'include' statement MUST NOT be used in a YANG The 'embed' statement MUST NOT be used in a YANG version 1
version 1 module, neither explicitly nor via a 'uses' module, neither explicitly nor via a 'uses' statement.
statement.
The 'include' statement MAY be present as a substatement
of 'container' and 'list' and MUST NOT be present elsewhere.
Whenever a sequence of 'include' statements is used, the The 'embed' statement MAY be present as a substatement of
schema tree defined by the set of the included modules is 'anydata' and MUST NOT be present elsewhere.
inserted in the schema tree of the calling module, at the
place where the sequence is declared"; Whenever a sequence of 'embed' statements is used, the schema
tree defined by the set of the included modules is inserted
in the schema tree of the calling module, at the place where
the sequence is declared";
} }
} }

8. Open issues 8. Open issues
* What name should we give to this draft? Any suggestions instead * What name should we give to this draft? Any suggestions instead
of full include? of full embed?
* Do we want to support the parent-nodes mechanism from [RFC8528]? * Do we want to support the parent-nodes mechanism from [RFC8528]?
(see below)
* Do we allow full include from within a grouping? * Do we allow full embed into an augment? We could even relax no
self-reference to have a module embed itself into another by
augmenting it?
* Does this mechanism already exist? * Does this mechanism already exist?
* Do we want to add a partial embed with an xpath instead of just
the prefix? The goal would be to include only part of a module.
This complexifies a bit the validation as leaf-ref, must, when and
other statement involving Xpath will need to be reinterpreted in
that new context.
8.1. Parent-nodes mechanism from schema mount
YANG Schema Mount includes a mechanism to make some nodes from the
embedding model available to the embedded model for validation
purposes. We could achieve the same by adding a second extension,
which can also only appear under a "full:embed" nodes. That
extension, for instance named "full:embed-parent-refs" would take a
Xpath expression as the in the "parent-reference" leaflist defined in
the YANG Schema Mount and would have the same semantics. If several
XPath are needed for clarity, the statement can be repeated with
several values.
As an example, Figure 1 restates the parent-references example from
[RFC8528] using this new extension. We might want to put some
restrictions on the nodes that can be referred to in the Xpath
argument.
...
import "ietf-routing" {
prefix "rt";
}
import "ietf-interfaces" {
prefix "if";
}
...
container network-instances {
list network-instance {
leaf name {...}
anydata root {
full:embed "rt" {
full:embed-parent-refs "if:interfaces/if:interface[\
ni:bind-network-instance-name = current()/../ni:name]";
}
// other full:embed if needed
}
}
}
Figure 1: Pseudo-YANG example of parent-references from [RFC8528]
with "full:embed"

Appendix A. Changes between revisions Appendix A. Changes between revisions
No revisions 00 -> 01
* Renamed full include -> full embed
* Require extension to appear in anydata for clients not supporting
extension
* Allow "if-feature" and "must" as sub-statement of full:embed,
explain that feature work at server level
Appendix B. Examples Appendix B. Examples
In this section we present some minimalistic examples in order to In this section we present some minimalistic examples in order to
illustrate the "full:include" statement. For these examples, we are illustrate the "full:embed" statement. For these examples, we are in
in a situation where we have a device-level module already defined a situation where we have a device-level module already defined and
and we want to have a network-level module that represent a list of we want to have a network-level module that represent a list of
device, each having an independent instance of the device-level device, each having an independent instance of the device-level
module. This situation might arise if we want to simplify the module. This situation might arise if we want to simplify the
network management by presenting a unified model for the network. In network management by presenting a unified model for the network. In
that case, the heterogeneity of the devices should be handled by that case, the heterogeneity of the devices should be handled by
mapping their model to the device-level module (which is clearly out mapping their model to the device-level module (which is clearly out
of scope for this draft). of scope for this draft).
In our simplistic example, the device-level module simply exposes the In our simplistic example, the device-level module simply exposes the
hostname and the cpu-usage of the device. Note that we cannot modify hostname and the cpu-usage of the device. Note that we cannot modify
this device-level module, because in a more realistic example we this device-level module, because in a more realistic example we
would be reusing standard modules. The tree representation would be reusing standard modules. The tree representation
([RFC8340]) of the 'device-level' module is depicted in Figure 1. ([RFC8340]) of the 'device-level' module is depicted in Figure 2.
module: device-level module: device-level
+--rw hostname string +--rw hostname string
+--ro cpu-usage? int8 +--ro cpu-usage? int8

B.1. Example using YANG Full Include B.1. Example using YANG Full Embed
We propose in this section a YANG module for 'network-level'. The We propose in this section a YANG module for 'network-level'. The
YANG code is presented in Figure 3. YANG code is presented in Figure 4.
module network-level { module network-level {
yang-version 1.1; yang-version 1.1;
namespace "urn:network-level"; namespace "urn:network-level";
prefix "net-l"; prefix "net-l";
import "ietf-yang-full-include" { import "ietf-yang-full-include" {
prefix "full"; prefix "full";
} }
import "device-level" { import "device-level" {
prefix "dev-l"; prefix "dev-l";
} }
container devices { container devices {
list device { list device {
key device-id; key device-id;
leaf device-id { leaf device-id {
type string; type string;
} }
full:include "dev-l"; anydata device-content {
full:include "dev-l";
}
} }
} }
} }
Figure 3: Version of the network-level module using full:include Figure 4: Version of the network-level module using full:embed
At the moment, this code is accepted by the YANG compilers, but since At the moment, this code is accepted by the YANG compilers, but since
the extension is not implemented, it simply ignores it. Note that the extension is not implemented, it simply ignores it. Note that
all the information (which modules to include, where to include them) all the information (which modules to embed, where to embed them) is
is defined in this module. More specifically, the line 'full:include defined in this module. More specifically, the line 'full:embed
"dev-l";' states that the full schema of the 'device-level' module, "dev-l";' states that the full schema of the 'device-level' module,
identified by its prefix "dev-l" must be included at that location. identified by its prefix "dev-l" must be embedded at that location.
By adding more occurrences of "full:include" there, one can define a By adding more occurrences of "full:embed" there, one can define a
more complex schema to be included at that location. more complex schema to be embedded at that location.
B.2. Using YANG Schema Mount B.2. Using YANG Schema Mount
In this section, we show how a similar result could be attained using In this section, we show how a similar result could be attained using
YANG Schema Mount. The network-level module is presented in YANG Schema Mount. The network-level module is presented in
Figure 4. Figure 5.
module network-level { module network-level {
yang-version 1.1; yang-version 1.1;
namespace "urn:network-level"; namespace "urn:network-level";
prefix "net-l"; prefix "net-l";
import ietf-yang-schema-mount { import ietf-yang-schema-mount {
prefix yangmnt; prefix yangmnt;
} }
container devices { container devices {
list device { list device {
key device-id; key device-id;
leaf device-id { leaf device-id {
type string; type string;
} }
yangmnt:mount-point "device-schema"; container device-contents{
yangmnt:mount-point "device-schema";
}
} }
} }
} }
Figure 4: Version of the network-level module using Schema Mount Figure 5: Version of the network-level module using Schema Mount

modules to include, as well as the data required by 'ietf-yang-mount' modules to embed, as well as the data required by 'ietf-yang-mount'
needs to be specified in some other files. Using the 'yanglint' tool needs to be specified in some other files. Using the 'yanglint' tool

compiled to provide a tree representation as shown in Figure 5. compiled to provide a tree representation as shown in Figure 6.
